snippet: A study showed that nonsmoking miners who were heavily exposed to diesel fumes had seven times the normal lung cancer risk of nonsmokers.
abstract: World Health Organization declares that diesel fumes cause lung cancer, saying they are more carcinogenic than secondhand cigarette smoke; decision is largely aimed at poor countries where diesel exhaust is more common, but it could eventually affect some American workers who are heavily exposed to the substance.
lead_paragraph: A study showed that nonsmoking miners who were heavily exposed to diesel fumes had seven times the normal lung cancer risk of nonsmokers.

headline.seo: Diesel Fumes Cause Lung Cancer, W.H.O. Says
headline.main: W.H.O. Declares Diesel Fumes Cause Lung Cancer
headline.print_headline: W.H.O. Declares Diesel Fumes Cause Lung Cancer
